column4: It depends on how the filesystem was set up, it can be anywhere from 16G to 2T
what is the filesystem default file size ? (ubuntu 8.04)
Actually, pastebin the output of "sudo fdisk -l" (thats an L)
Or, if you know which device it is (/dev/sdXY) you can just give the output of this: sudo /sbin/dumpe2fs /dev/sdXY | grep "Block size"
what is the output of: sudo /sbin/dumpe2fs /dev/sda1 | grep "Block size"
don't need to pastebin, it should only be one line (and we really just need the number)
Alright, your max file size is 2TB
thanks for your help :) can i ask you another question ?
what is the best compression tool in ubuntu ?

Well, most people either use gzip or bzip2, (.gz and .bz2)  But the compression amount depends on what sort of data youre compressing as much as what compression method you're using.  Either would be a fine choice
i never used .gz tool , can you give me an example how i can compress folder with her sub-folders ?

Theres a graphical tool which will make it easy.  You actually do it in two steps.  gz only compresses a single file, so first you have to make all the files into a single file (called a tar).  Its a two step process (except you don't see the steps individually usually).  This is why you sometimes see .tar.gz (which is sometimes shortened to .tgz)
